trans-unit.source: Defines a keyboard combination that can be used to invoke a command.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> must be associated with one or more <xref:System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys>.
The exceptions to this rule are the function keys and the numeric keypad keys, which can be a valid <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by themselves.
For example, you can create a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by using only the F12 key, but to use the X key in a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> it must be paired with a modifier key.
In general, you can

You can use a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyBinding> to bind a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> to an <xref:System.Windows.Input.ICommand>, so that the command is invoked when the <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> occurs.

For <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] usages, the property that is generally set in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] is <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyBinding.Gesture%2A>, in cases where the gesture represents both a standard key and a modifier key.
You can also set the <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyBinding.Gesture%2A> property to be just a function key, or just a modifier key combination.

However, it is more common to set the <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyBinding.Key%2A> property if the intended command binding is a function key with no modifiers, or <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyBinding.Modifiers%2A> if the intended command binding is for modifier keys only.
XAML Attribute Usage
XAML Values
A single key value, which must be one of the function keys (F1-12) or numeric keypad keys.
One or more modifier keys, defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys> enumeration, delimited with a "+" character.
A single key value.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref> class with the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Input.Key"></xref>.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> must be associated with one or more <xref:System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys>.
The exceptions to this rule are the function keys and the numeric keypad keys, which can be a valid <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by themselves.
The key associated with this gesture.
key is not a valid .
key is not a valid .

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref> class with the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Input.Key"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys"></xref>.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> must be associated with one or more <xref:System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys>.
The exceptions to this rule are the function keys and the numeric keypad keys, which can be a valid <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by themselves.
The key associated with the gesture.
The modifier keys associated with the gesture.
modifiers is not a valid
-or-
key is not a valid .
key and modifiers do not form a valid .

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref> class with the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Input.Key"></xref>, <xref href="System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys"></xref>, and display string.
The <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture.DisplayString%2A> property is set to the `displayString` parameter.
The key associated with the gesture.
The modifier keys associated with the gesture.
A string representation of the <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>.
modifiers is not a valid
-or-
key is not a valid .
displayString is `null`.
key and modifiers do not form a valid .
Gets a string representation of this <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>.
If a display string was not set in the constructor, an empty string is returned.

If this property is empty, the <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture.GetDisplayStringForCulture%2A> method returns a string created from the <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture.Key%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture.Modifiers%2A>.
The display string for this <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>.
The default value is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Returns a string that can be used to display the <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>.

If the display string was set by the constructor, that string is returned; otherwise, a string is created from the <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture.Key%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture.Modifiers%2A> with any necessary conversions being governed by the specified <xref:System.Globalization.CultureInfo> object.
The culture specific information.
The string to display
Gets the key associated with this <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> must be associated with one or more <xref:System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys>.
The exceptions to this rule are the function keys and the numeric keypad keys, which can be a valid <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by themselves.
The key associated with the gesture.
The default value is <xref href="System.Windows.Input.Key.None"></xref>.
Determines whether this <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref> matches the input associated with the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Input.InputEventArgs"></xref> object.
`targetElement` can be used to make a more specific decision on whether a command should be invoked on a specific element.
The target.
The input event data to compare this gesture to.
`true` if the event data matches this <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the modifier keys associated with this <xref href="System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture"></xref>.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> must be associated with one or more <xref:System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys>.
The exceptions to this rule are the function keys and the numeric keypad keys, which can be a valid <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by themselves.
For example, you can create a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> by using only the F12 key, but to use the X key in a <xref:System.Windows.Input.KeyGesture> it must be paired with a modifier key.
The modifier keys associated with the gesture.
The default value is <xref href="System.Windows.Input.ModifierKeys.None"></xref>.
